title: Keep Fit(a Bit) in Kalamaki: First web based* attempt to make Kalamaki a "Smart City"
segmentation: Good morning.
My name is Elias, me and Yakobo and Emma and Max.
We are part of the group fit people.
And we're really proud to introduce to you an idea of keeping fit at least a bit in kalamaki.
Which which actually is the first web based attempt to make kalamaki smart City.
So let me tell you the story of Fred, Fred, an Irish guy, as you might can see.
Fred lives in Dublin.
Dublin is, as we mentioned, for Smart City.
Fred is also sports into theists.
He observes his own energy consumption and his cane, or in a digital way back at home in Dublin.
Fred is going on a holiday to Kalamaki, so of course Fred wants to stay fit.
But the question is how to stay fit in a place like Kalamaki where you barely can walk far and have a lot of awesome food.
So let me explain what smart cities smart cities is City providing link data about economic development, transport, public transportation, social services, and the most important thing.
Of course about food.
So our goal was to somehow develop something like a personalized personalized health planner.
Especially for Fred and his trip to Kalamaki, so it should almost look like like this.
We have Fred.
He's using the person less health planner once he gives the health planner and data is his age, his weight, his hate gender, and of course he's pushing in kalamaki.
The personalized health planner gathers data from the Fitbit.
Stuff is Fred is wearing all time while walking around in kalamaki and of course at home in Dublin.
The Health Center also takes the data from different menus.
What he actually gets from the smart city Kalamaki he compares the database to find out nutrition facts about food, like the energy content, the calories of given food.
And we take map data from Openstreetmaps, and what our friend Fred gets back is a list of restaurants.
Around in kalamaki the dishes the restaurants offer the energy of the different dishes.

Of course the prices of dishes, The Walking differences between places like his hotel, the restaurant, the beach, the nudist beach and of course an overview of his own personal personal energy balance.
So we did actually three things.
We started with data collection.
We collected RDF triples.
The total steps per day on the Fitbit API.
We collected non digital data, the restaurant menus, the HTML data.
The calories are totally before in the database of.
Some service provider and the geographic data on Openstreetmap, so RDF from the Fitbit.
Well, our code team made them.
They had a pretty hard time collecting the offline data, but it was especially good.
She did a good job.
Then we have the HTML data, the nutrition facts, and the Openstreetmap.
The second thing we did was the data integration.
We RDF, RDF cessation.
We did already infestation.
This is actually word.
Thank you very much.
We are to fight the knowledge and data and data we got from the website.
We stored it well due to the Internet connection to our local triple store.
We did several SPARQL queries, for example like give me all the menus and dishes with the nutrition facts from a given restaurant based on my position.
And the third thing we were doing was implementing of the web based prototype.
The computations of the calories from the cellular dishes to sum up within a menu computation.
How much did he lose?
How much did he gain overview in a in a progress bar?
We integrated it with the data from the back end.
And of course, the graphical user interface.
So now Jacobi is going to show you a quick demo.
OK here yeah this is the basic basic interface here.
The idea of this interface is to like a diary where you can log the activities you had and also the food you want to come some.
For example, if on Saturday I want to eat moussaka.
Yeah, first we have to feed to synchronize everything.
For example, let's say I want to eat moussaka.
Then the system will automatically update my consumption.

I will in this bar I will have the log of the calories that I need to still to get or the color that I need to consume doing fit, and then there is also the other interface, the health planner that allows me to simulate.
What where, where are restaurants and facilities I can I can have in the city and choose some places and see them.
Now we have some problems with the map, I think because of the connection so we can get them.
The basic idea was for example to clicking on on shop and see what was provided.
And yes they work, but today not.
And then we can.
This is the simulation.
If I go there and it is how my calories changes.
And so, and that's all.
OK, well some Internet issues, but if you're interested we can provide some working examples online if we are back in normal Internet world.
The future steps of our project are going to be the publishing of the Kalamaki data on Openstreetmap.
As Yakubu mentioned, the restaurants the prices to calories etc to actually make do a little bit forward sintos direction of smart city kalamaki.
We want to generalize our ideas to make it easy for other cities to adopt our system in as soon as they get smart cities.
Yeah, also of course some social features like the sharing the activities and consumption of energy ahead on a given day.
Compared with other users and.
And exchange lifestyles like I lost the kilograms by doing something the other person says, wow, I live there are two.
I'll do the same thing.
Let's have the same walking routes or running routes and then afterwards have some dish at the same restaurant together.
We want to include weather data to see maybe some forecast to see.
Well, today is not a good day to walk up to the auto town because it's going to be stormy whatever.
And very cool point would be to include health data like personal health things like which illnesses to have.
Can I go running with my approaching heart disease?
The allergies not go out and weather?
Where is pollution all over there and stuff like this?
Alright, so we are actually the first team ever to enabling Kalamaki as a smart city.
Thank you for watching us.
And of course thank you for TD and Sean for the awesome support they gave us, thanks.
